instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD: What is WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD? This is a signal from the keyboard for the left shift key, which is significantly different from the right shift key when it comes to resetting the SMC/PRAM. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no video but <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> present
threads.message:
Didn't yet erased the crime scene  from this slightly water damaged board.

Initial issue: fan spins, green/orange light ok, no chime no video, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> present <SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> not present.
Both RAM A&B not detected. (1 beep ram).
I solved the no ram detection, it was the DATA smbus line talking to the pch being pulled down by a low short coming from bad looking <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> area (sharing same data lines with PCH). Just isolated the communication with <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> by removing <RESISTOR>R9757</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9753</RESISTOR>.

Now Ram A & B are working properly, I have all rails.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> 0,77v
<SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> 0,45v not sure if it's too low I know it's dynamic.
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> ok
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area clean, Checked <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL> continuity and resistor and all is ok.

Now I am lost, what could prevent the board from chiming  when <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> are present?
Bios? Should I remove <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> right now or not relevant at this stage. Also <SIGNAL>WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD</SIGNAL> pin is broken but don't think important for now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no video but <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> present
threads.message: Do a PRAM reset with an external USB keyboard. Also you can connect a USB mouse and if the light comes on the board is working.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no chime no video but <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AXG_VCORE</SIGNAL> present
threads.message:
Thanks, solved! You were right, 
Usb connected gave a red light. Plugged an external keyboard and PRAMÂ´ed the board.

Conclusion: water dammaged <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> witch pulled down a shared pch bus data line that prevent detection of SODIMM A and B + logic board needed a pram.
